label: Gen. P. G. T. Beauregard Letter, June 25, 1863
description: This letter from Gen. Pierre Gustave Toutant Beauregard (1818-1893) to South Carolina Gov. Milledge Luke Bonham (1813-1890) was written from his headquarters in Charleston, South Carolina, on June 25, 1863. Gen. P.G.T. Beauregard became the first brigadier general in the Confederate States Army. He commanded the defenses of Charleston, South Carolina, on April 12, 1861, and later returned to defend the city from repeated attacks by U.S. forces. This letter is in reference to the defense of the battery at Taber's Point on the Santee River. Signed original. Paper watermarked WEBB & HUNT, LIVERPOOL with an anchor symbol.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Head-Quarters
Department of So. Ca. Ga. and Fla.
Charleston S.C. June 25th 1863.

To his Excellency,
Gov. M. L. Bonham
Columbia S.C.
Sir, 
Your letter of the 19th inst. enclosing the original report of Major Niernsee on the obstruction of the Santee River and Battery at Taber's point has been received, and I return herewith his lucid report. I can find in my files no correspondence with the State Mily. Council relative to that Battery - but my impression is that I agreed to give a few guns for it, if practicable; but since that period, I have had to send additional guns to Georgetown and other points in the Department, which leaves neither guns or Artillerists for the Taber Battery. 
In case of necessity, however, 
[page 2]
one of the siege train batteries could be sent there - One or two traverses in the Battery would have added greatly to its strength and efficiency. I will remark here, that Captain Gaillard's Light Arty. Company is in charge of a Battery at Lenud's ferry on the Santee - with 2 heavy and 4 light pieces, of which 3 are rifled. 
Respectfully
Your obt. Servant. 
G. T. Beauregard
Gen. Comdg
[page 3]
Genl. Beauregard
June 25, 1863
As to Maj. Niernsee's Report
